title: The possibility of making $138,000 from shredded banknote pieces using computer vision
description:
Every country must dispose of old banknotes. At the Hong Kong Monetary Authority visitor center, visitors can buy a paperweight souvenir full of shredded banknotes. Even though the shredded banknotes are small, by using computer vision, it is possible to reconstruct the whole banknote like a jigsaw puzzle. Each paperweight souvenir costs $100 HKD, and it is claimed to contain shredded banknotes equivalent to 138 complete $1000 HKD banknotes. In theory, $138,000 HKD can be recovered by using computer vision. This paper discusses the technique of collecting shredded banknote pieces and applying a computer vision program.

arXiv
description_plain:
Every country must dispose of old banknotes. At the Hong Kong Monetary Authority visitor center, visitors can buy a paperweight souvenir full of shredded banknotes. Even though the shredded banknotes are small, by using computer vision, it is possible to reconstruct the whole banknote like a jigsaw puzzle. Each paperweight souvenir costs $100 HKD, and it is claimed to contain shredded banknotes equivalent to 138 complete $1000 HKD banknotes. In theory, $138,000 HKD can be recovered by using computer vision. This paper discusses the technique of collecting shredded banknote pieces and applying a computer vision program.

[arXiv](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.06133)

title: Resources on building robust ETL pipelines
description:
I‚Äôm aware of basic stuff like:

  • make jobs idempotent/incremental
  • try to keep configuration flags standard across jobs
  • make data input/output artifacts apparent by passing them explicitly and/or logging their full paths
  • eliminate toil (from the Google SRE book)
  • try set up alerting in a way that avoids alarm fatigue

But I can‚Äôt think of any specific resources that have practical advice on how to structure scripts, (sane) documentation standards to enforce, and how to design pipelines. I guess some ops tools have docs with suggestions specific to that project (e.g. Airflow), but I think some of these ideas are a bit more general. Any recommendations for books/blogs/case studies? Google seems to have a lot of this stuff figured out, so maybe some devops/SRE blogs from Googlers?

(I specifically want to improve currently existing pipelines at work so support rotations suck less, and avoid certain structural pitfalls when building new pipelines so I don‚Äôt make the ops work any more of a dumpster fire)
description_plain:
I'm aware of basic stuff like: 
* make jobs idempotent/incremental 
* try to keep configuration flags standard across jobs
* make data input/output artifacts apparent by passing them explicitly and/or logging their full paths
* eliminate toil (from the Google SRE book)
* try set up alerting in a way that avoids alarm fatigue

But I can't think of any specific resources that have practical advice on how to structure scripts, (sane) documentation standards to enforce, and how to design pipelines. I guess some ops tools have docs with suggestions specific to that project (e.g. Airflow), but I think some of these ideas are a bit more general. Any recommendations for books/blogs/case studies? Google seems to have a lot of this stuff figured out, so maybe some devops/SRE blogs from Googlers?

(I specifically want to improve currently existing pipelines at work so support rotations suck less, and avoid certain structural pitfalls when building new pipelines so I don't make the ops work any more of a dumpster fire)
